--- In junit@y..., Mike Clark <mike@c...> wrote:

> If the custom assertions are used in only one test case, I'll just defined
> those assertions within the specialized test case itself.  This gives me to
> option to refactor them into a base test case later if necessary.


That sounds like a good plan for a first step as I'm not sure whether or not I'll 
need these custom assertions in future test cases. Nor do I know if my initial 
assumptions on how to write these custom assertions will be correct the first 
time around and applicable for future versions of test cases.

With regards to possible second steps (future refactorings)....

>If the custom assertions are used by many test cases, I'll typically use this
>approach:

>public class BaseTestCase extends TestCase {
>//...

--- In junit@y...,  Vladimir Bossicard <vladimir@b...> wrote:
>Unlike the "new TestCase" option, you can :
>- have multiple assertEqual(Object, Object) methods
>- use several user-defined Assert classes in one TestCase object
>- easily share your assertions, users don't have to redefine one 
>TestCase class to use your assertions (2 classes instead of one)

...Which of these two ways would you consider, in the context of Extreme 
Programming, to be the "Simplest Thing Which Could Possibly Work"?

At first glance it seems that making a new specialized TestCase (i.e.- 
inheritance) to contain the custom assertion methods would be the quickest way 
to add these on. Just push them up into a new base class.

However, the specialized Assert class (i.e.-delegation) appears to be more 
flexible and easier to change in the future. It also seems to better communicate 
the purpose of the new class.

In other words, if I went with the new TestCase extension route, I'm not sure 
whether I'll remember 6 months down the road that I created the new TestCase 
class to hold the custom assertions. Where as making calls to an specialized 
Assert class route would likely to be more understandable.

What are your thoughts on the matter of simplicity and readability vs. ease of 
initial implementation with regards to these choices? I'm trying to stick to the 
Extreme Programming way of doing things.

Thanks,

Anthony
